div.head: Plates
div.p:

div.p:

app.note: I assume that an upadhmānīya was intended here. Autopsy may tell whether it is in all respects identical to an ṣ, as found in lines 11 and 13 of the Diggubaṟṟu grant of Bhīma II.

Throughout this passage, I show the text as read and emended by Hultzsch because lacking access to a facsimile, I prefer not to alter his readings. However, I believe that the passage is in fact a stanza in gīti (or a related metre). Given that there is definitely a gīti unnoticed by Hultzsch starting in line 23, I think the present passage, though it needs more intervention, was also intended to be one. The composer's intent may have been something like the following: yas tātabikyanākhyam ujjvala-mūrttir iva rāja-mārttaṇḍaḥ| Ājau vijitya bāhvor ggāpayati janair nnijaṁ janoddharaṇam|| I am of course most uncertain about my Sanskrit suggestion for the possibly vernacular segment nvaḻadimunniṟiva. In addition, my janoddharaṇam is not very good in the context, though still more appropriate than Hultzsch's janodāharaṇaṁ, which he translates fame without any comment. I prefer bāhvor to Hultzsch's bāhvā on the one hand because it assumes a much smaller scribal mistake, and on the other because a dual would be expected here. Nonetheless, bāhvā is entirely possible and perhaps slightly better semantically, given the presence of nijam.

Read by Hultzsch as prose, I am certain that this was intended to be a gīti stanza, emboldened by the presence of punctuation after both halves and in both cases inconsistent with the syntax and thus intended for verse segmentation. The second hemistich is unmetrical, with an extra syllable at the end. One way to resolve this is to emend kṣitīśas tena to kṣitīśena. But given the structure of the composition with a snatch of connecting prose after the stanza, I think the composer rather had something like kṣitīśo 'sti in mind, followed by tena in the connecting prose rather than within the stanza. I thus believe we have a scribal error in the text as well as in the position of the punctuation mark.
Hultzsch prints the first character as a clear de, but observes that there is a crack to the right of it, and that it may have been pe.
I am baffled by this glaringly unmetrical line and have no suggestions to improve it.
I find sv-abhijana better in the context than Hultzsch's emendation svābhijana.
Although I know of no attestation for vāra-goṣṭhī, I think the compound can be interpreted in the context without resorting to emendation.

div.p: Edited (probably from the original) by E. Hultzsch (43-4637), with translation but no facsimile. The present edition by Dániel Balogh follows Hultzsch's text unless otherwise noted in the apparatus.The original plates are probably still in the Madras Museum, listead as Chāḷukyas, Eastern 13 in 6, so the edition may be collated with the plates.
